17329  * resulting in the most restrictive one being used.
17330  * <p>
17331  * The generated ticks are separated by a 
17332  * <i>step</i> value.
17333  * A step value is a certain power of 
17334  * <tt>10</tt>,
17335  * possibly multiplied by 
17336  * <tt>2</tt> or 
17337  * <tt>5</tt>.
17338  * <p>
17339  * For example, 
17340  * for a chosen exponent of 
17341  * <tt>4</tt>,
17342  * the corresponding power of 
17343  * <tt>10</tt> is 
17344  * <tt>10^4=10000</tt> and
17345  * the generated ticks could be:
17346  * 
17347  * <tt>0</tt>, 
17348  * <tt>10000</tt>, 
17349  * <tt>20000</tt>, ...
17350  * <p>
17351  * If the multiplier 
17352  * <tt>5</tt> was chosen, 
17353  * those ticks would instead be:
17354  * 
17355  * <tt>0</tt>, 
17356  * <tt>50000</tt>, 
17357  * <tt>100000</tt>, ...
17358  * <p>
17359  * Setting this property allows imposing a limit on 
17360  * the size of numbers chosen to separate ticks,
17361  * which may be seen as imposing a minimum granularity 
17362  * on the generated tick values.
17363  * <p>
17364  * See {@link #tickUnit} for more information.
17365  * 
17366  * @type number
17367  * @category Continuous-Numeric > Style
17368  */
17369 pvc.options.axes.NumericCartesianAxis.prototype.tickExponentMax = undefined;
17370 /**
17371  * The minimum exponent of 
17372  * <tt>10</tt> that is used to generate ticks (applies to continuous-numeric axes).
17373  * <p>
17374  * The value of this option is combined with that of {@link #tickUnitMax},
17375  * resulting in the most restrictive one being used.
17376  * <p>
17377  * The generated ticks are separated by a 
17378  * <i>step</i> value.
17379  * A step value is a certain power of 
17380  * <tt>10</tt>,
17381  * possibly multiplied by 
17382  * <tt>2</tt> or 
17383  * <tt>5</tt>.
17384  * <p>
17385  * For example, 
17386  * for a chosen exponent of 
17387  * <tt>2</tt>,
17388  * the corresponding power of 
17389  * <tt>10</tt> is 
17390  * <tt>10^2=100</tt> and
17391  * the generated ticks could be:
17392  * 
17393  * <tt>0</tt>, 
17394  * <tt>100</tt>, 
17395  * <tt>200</tt>, ...
17396  * <p>
17397  * If the multiplier 
17398  * <tt>2</tt> was chosen, 
17399  * those ticks would instead be:
17400  * 
17401  * <tt>0</tt>, 
17402  * <tt>200</tt>, 
17403  * <tt>400</tt>, ...
17404  * <p>
17405  * Setting this property to 
17406  * <tt>2</tt> would ensure 
17407  * that generated ticks would be separated by the step values
17408  * 
17409  * <tt>100</tt>, 
17410  * <tt>200</tt> or 
17411  * <tt>500</tt>,
17412  * or by steps whose corresponding exponent is 
17413  * bigger than 
17414  * <tt>2</tt>, 
17415  * like: 
17416  * <tt>1000</tt>, 
17417  * <tt>2000</tt> or 
17418  * <tt>5000</tt>.
17419  * <p>
17420  * A more typical use case is ensuring that generated ticks are integers.
17421  * A value of 
17422  * <tt>tickExponentMin</tt> of 
17423  * <tt>0</tt> would accomplish that.
17424  * <p>
17425  * Generally, 
17426  * to impose a maximum number of decimal places on the generated ticks, 
17427  * a negative number can be specified.
17428  * For example, the value 
17429  * <tt>-1</tt> could generate the ticks:
17430  * 
17431  * <tt>0.1</tt>, 
17432  * <tt>0.2</tt>, 
17433  * <tt>0.3</tt>, ...
17434  * If the multiplier 
17435  * <tt>5</tt> was chosen, 
17436  * those ticks would instead be:
17437  * 
17438  * <tt>0.5</tt>, 
17439  * <tt>1.0</tt>, 
17440  * <tt>1.5</tt>, ...
17441  * It could not generate ticks 
17442  * with more that one decimal place.
17443  * <p>
17444  * See {@link #tickUnit} for more information.
17445  * 
17446  * @type number
17447  * @category Continuous-Numeric > Style
17448  */
17449 pvc.options.axes.NumericCartesianAxis.prototype.tickExponentMin = undefined;
17450 /**
17451  * Indicates if the zero line rule is drawn, 
17452  * on the position of the 0-valued tick, 
17453  * when there is one (applies to continuous-numeric axes).
17454  * <p>
17455  * An horizontal axis has a vertical zero line rule,
17456  * while a a vertical axis has an horizontal zero line rule.
17457  * 
17458  * @type boolean
17459  * @default true
17460  * @category Continuous-Numeric > Style
17461  */
17462 pvc.options.axes.NumericCartesianAxis.prototype.zeroLine = undefined;
17463 /**
17464  * The minimum spacing between tick labels, in 
17465  * <i>em</i> units 
17466  * (does not apply to discrete-hierarchical axes).
17467  * <p>
17468  * Attention:
17469  * In continuous axes,
17470  * this option is ignored when {@link pvc.options.axes.AnyContinuousCartesianAxis#tickUnit}
17471  * is specified,
17472  * or when only two or three ticks are used!
17473  * <p>
17474  * See {@link pvc.options.axes.AnyContinuousCartesianAxis#tickUnit} for more information.
17475  * 
17476  * @type number
17477  * @category Non-Hierarchical > Layout
17478  */
17479 pvc.options.axes.NumericCartesianAxis.prototype.labelSpacingMin = undefined;
17480 /**
17481  * Indicates if ticks are shown for each tick value 
17482  * (does not apply to discrete-hierarchical axes).
17483  * 
17484  * @type boolean
17485  * @default true
17486  * @category Non-Hierarchical > Style
17487  */
17488 pvc.options.axes.NumericCartesianAxis.prototype.ticks = undefined;
17489 /**
17490  * The extension points object contains style definitions for 
17491  * the marks of the panel.
17492  * 
17493  * @type pvc.options.ext.NumericCartesianAxisExtensionPoints
17494  * @category Style
17495  */
17496 pvc.options.axes.NumericCartesianAxis.prototype.extensionPoints = undefined;
17497 /**
17498  * The extension points of the cartesian axis panel for continuous scale types.
17499  * <p>
17500  * Axes extension points can also be specified directly at the chart options level.
17501  * <p>
17502  * To use an extension point you must find its full name, by joining:
17503  * 
17504  * <ol>
17505  * 
17506  * <li>panel property name (ex: 
17507  * <tt>xAxis</tt>)</li>
17508  * 
17509  * <li>extension property (ex: 
17510  * <tt>zeroLine</tt>)</li>
17511  * 
17512  * <li>the "_" character</li>
17513  * 
17514  * <li>extension sub-property (ex: 
17515  * <tt>lineWidth</tt>)</li>
17516  * </ol>
17517  * and obtaining, for the examples, the camel-cased name: 
17518  * <tt>xAxisZeroLine_lineWidth</tt>
17519  * (see {@link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CamelCase}).
17520  * 
17521  * @class
17522  * @extends pvc.options.ext.CartesianAxisExtensionPoints
17523  */
17524 pvc.options.ext.NumericCartesianAxisExtensionPoints = function(){};
17525         
17526         
17527         
17528         
17529 /**
17530  * The extension point of the axis' scale object (applies to continuous axes).
17531  * 
17532  * @type pvc.options.marks.QuantitativeScaleExtensionPoint
17533  * @category Continuous > Scale
17534  */
17535 pvc.options.ext.NumericCartesianAxisExtensionPoints.prototype.scale = undefined;
17536 /**
17537  * The extension point of a 
17538  * <i>minor</i> tick rule mark (applies to continuous axes).
17539  * 
17540  * @type pvc.options.marks.RuleExtensionPoint
17541  * @category Continuous > Style
17542  */
17543 pvc.options.ext.NumericCartesianAxisExtensionPoints.prototype.minorTicks = undefined;
17544 /**
17545  * The extension point of the zero line rule (applies to continuous-numeric axes).
17546  * 
17547  * @type pvc.options.marks.RuleExtensionPoint
17548  * @category Continuous-Numeric > Style
17549  */
17550 pvc.options.ext.NumericCartesianAxisExtensionPoints.prototype.zeroLine = undefined;
17551 /**
17552  * The extension point of a discrete,
17553  * or continuous 
17554  * <i>major</i>,
17555  * tick rule mark (does not apply to discrete-hierarchical axes).
17556  * 
17557  * @type pvc.options.marks.RuleExtensionPoint
17558  * @category Non-Hierarchical > Style
17559  */
17560 pvc.options.ext.NumericCartesianAxisExtensionPoints.prototype.ticks = undefined;
17561 /**
17562  * The extension point of the tick panel 
17563  * (does not apply to discrete-hierarchical axes).
17564  * <p>
17565  * One tick panel contains one tick rule and one label.
17566  * It can be used to conveniently hide all the elements 
17567  * of a tick simultaneously.
17568  * 
17569  * @type pvc.options.marks.PanelExtensionPoint
17570  * @category Non-Hierarchical > Style
17571  */
17572 pvc.options.ext.NumericCartesianAxisExtensionPoints.prototype.ticksPanel = undefined;
17573 /**
17574  * The namespace of CCC panels options classes. 
17575  * 
17576  * @namespace
17577  */
17578 pvc.options.panels = {};
17579 
17580 /**
17581  * The common options documentation class of the CCC panels.
17582  * 
17583  * @class
17584  * @abstract
17585  */
17586 pvc.options.panels.Panel = function(){};
17587         
17588         
17589         
17590         
17591 /**
17592  * The fixed size of the panel, in pixel units or as a percentage.
17593  * <p>
17594  * See {@link pvc.options.varia.Size} for information about 
17595  * the different supported data types.
17596  * 
17597  * @type number|string|pvc.options.varia.Size
17598  * @category Layout
17599  */
17600 pvc.options.panels.Panel.prototype.size = undefined;
17601 /**
17602  * The maximum size of the panel, in pixel units or as a percentage.
17603  * <p>
17604  * See {@link pvc.options.varia.Size} for information about 
17605  * the different supported data types.
17606  * 
17607  * @type number|string|pvc.options.varia.Size
17608  * @category Layout
17609  */
17610 pvc.options.panels.Panel.prototype.sizeMax = undefined;
17611 /**
17612  * The common options documentation class of CCC docked panels.
17613  * 
17614  * @class
17615  * @extends pvc.options.panels.Panel
17616  * @abstract
17617  */
17618 pvc.options.panels.DockedPanel = function(){};
17619         
17620         
17621         
17622         
17623 /**
17624  * The alignment side of the panel (the source)
17625  * that will align to a side of the parent panel (the target).
17626  * <p>
17627  * The alignment side must be 
17628  * orthogonal to the docking side.
17629  * <p>
17630  * The default value is 
17631  * <tt>'middle'</tt>,
17632  * if {@link pvc.options.panels.DockedPanel#position}
17633  * is an horizontal side, 
17634  * and 
17635  * <tt>'center'</tt>, otherwise.
17636  * 
17637  * @type pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentSource
17638  * @category Layout
17639  */
17640 pvc.options.panels.DockedPanel.prototype.align = undefined;
17641 /**
17642  * The margins of the panel.
17643  * <p>
17644  * See {@link pvc.options.varia.Sides} for information about 
17645  * the different supported data types.
17646  * 
17647  * @type number|string|pvc.options.varia.Sides
17648  * @default 0
17649  * @category Layout
17650  */
17651 pvc.options.panels.DockedPanel.prototype.margins = undefined;
17652 /**
17653  * The paddings of the panel.
17654  * <p>
17655  * See {@link pvc.options.varia.Sides} for information about 
17656  * the different supported data types.
17657  * 
17658  * @type number|string|pvc.options.varia.Sides
17659  * @default 0
17660  * @category Layout
17661  */
17662 pvc.options.panels.DockedPanel.prototype.paddings = undefined;
17663 /**
17664  * The docking position of the panel.
17665  * 
17666  * @type pvc.options.varia.PanelPosition
17667  * @category Layout
17668  */
17669 pvc.options.panels.DockedPanel.prototype.position = undefined;
17670 /**
17671  * The font of the panel.
17672  * <p>
17673  * See the supported font format in 
17674  * {@link http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/fonts.html#font-shorthand}
17675  * 
17676  * @type string
17677  * @category Style
17678  */
17679 pvc.options.panels.DockedPanel.prototype.font = undefined;
17680 /**
17681  * The options documentation class of the legend panel.
17682  * 
17683  * @class
17684  * @extends pvc.options.panels.DockedPanel
17685  */
17686 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel = function(){};
17687         
17688         
17689         
17690         
17691 /**
17692  * The maximum positive number of legend items that can fit in the legend panel.
17693  * <p>
17694  * See {@link pvc.options.varia.LegendOverflow} for information about
17695  * the different behaviors of the legend panel when this maximum is exceeded.
17696  * 
17697  * @type number
17698  * @category Layout
17699  */
17700 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel.prototype.itemCountMax = undefined;
17701 /**
17702  * Half the space between legend items, in pixel units.
17703  * 
17704  * <p>
17705  * This property should be named "itemMargins", according to the current naming and box model concept, 
17706  * but is as is for historical reasons.
17707  * </p>
17708  * 
17709  * <p>
17710  * Percentage values are in relation to the legend panel's available client size 
17711  * (i.e. the available size with margins and paddings discounted).
17712  * </p>
17713  * 
17714  * <p>
17715  * The item margins are only applied 
17716  * <i>between</i> items.
17717  * </p>
17718  * 
17719  * <p>
17720  * See {@link pvc.options.varia.Sides} for information about 
17721  * the different supported data types.
17722  * </p>
17723  * 
17724  * @type number|string|pvc.options.varia.Sides
17725  * @default 2.5
17726  * @category Layout
17727  */
17728 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel.prototype.itemPadding = undefined;
17729 /**
17730  * The fixed size of legend items, in pixel units or as a percentage.
17731  * 
17732  * <p>
17733  * The size includes {@link #itemPadding}.
17734  * The items' client size is the size discounted of the item padding.
17735  * </p>
17736  * 
17737  * <p>
17738  * Percentage values are in relation to the legend panel's available client size 
17739  * (i.e. the available size with margins and paddings discounted).
17740  * </p>
17741  * 
17742  * <p>
17743  * When unspecified, each item assumes the smallest possible size that fits all content.
17744  * You can specify only the item's width or height.
17745  * </p>
17746  * 
17747  * <p>
17748  * The default item height is the biggest of the font height and the {@link #markerSize}.
17749  * The default item width is 
17750  * the {@link #markerSize}, 
17751  * plus the {@link #textMargin}, 
17752  * plus the width of the item's text at the current font.
17753  * </p>
17754  * 
17755  * <p>
17756  * See {@link pvc.options.varia.Size} for information about 
17757  * the different supported data types.
17758  * </p>
17759  * 
17760  * @type number|string|pvc.options.varia.Size
17761  * @category Layout
17762  */
17763 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel.prototype.itemSize = undefined;
17764 /**
17765  * The width and height of the marker panel, in pixel units.
17766  * <p>
17767  * The marker itself will be slightly smaller.
17768  * 
17769  * @type number
17770  * @default 15
17771  * @category Layout
17772  */
17773 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel.prototype.markerSize = undefined;
17774 /**
17775  * The behavior of the legend panel when an overflow is detected.
17776  * <p>
17777  * See {@link pvc.options.varia.LegendOverflow} for information about
17778  * the different behaviors of the legend panel when an overflow is detected.
17779  * 
17780  * @type string|pvc.options.varia.LegendOverflow
17781  * @default 'clip'
17782  * @category Layout
17783  */
17784 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel.prototype.overflow = undefined;
17785 /**
17786  * The paddings of the panel.
17787  * <p>
17788  * See {@link pvc.options.varia.Sides} for information about 
17789  * the different supported data types.
17790  * 
17791  * @type number|string|pvc.options.varia.Sides
17792  * @default 5
17793  * @category Layout
17794  */
17795 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel.prototype.paddings = undefined;
17796 /**
17797  * The docking position of the panel.
17798  * 
17799  * @type pvc.options.varia.PanelPosition
17800  * @default 'bottom'
17801  * @category Layout
17802  */
17803 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel.prototype.position = undefined;
17804 /**
17805  * The space between the marker and the associated label, in pixel units.
17806  * 
17807  * @type number
17808  * @default 6
17809  * @category Layout
17810  */
17811 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel.prototype.textMargin = undefined;
17812 /**
17813  * The extension points provided by the legend panel.
17814  * 
17815  * @type pvc.options.ext.LegendPanelExtensionPoints
17816  * @category Style
17817  */
17818 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel.prototype.extensionPoints = undefined;
17819 /**
17820  * The font of the panel.
17821  * <p>
17822  * See the supported font format in 
17823  * {@link http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/fonts.html#font-shorthand}
17824  * 
17825  * @type string
17826  * @default '10px sans-serif'
17827  * @category Style
17828  */
17829 pvc.options.panels.LegendPanel.prototype.font = undefined;
17830 /**
17831  * The extension points of the legend panel.
17832  * <p>
17833  * Legend extension points can also be specified directly at the chart options level.
17834  * <p>
17835  * To use an extension point you must find its full name, by joining:
17836  * 
17837  * <ol>
17838  * 
17839  * <li>panel property name (ex: 
17840  * <tt>legend</tt>)</li>
17841  * 
17842  * <li>extension property (ex: 
17843  * <tt>label</tt>)</li>
17844  * 
17845  * <li>the "_" character</li>
17846  * 
17847  * <li>extension sub-property (ex: 
17848  * <tt>textStyle</tt>)</li>
17849  * </ol>
17850  * and obtaining, for the examples, the camel-cased name: 
17851  * <tt>legendLabel_textStyle</tt>
17852  * (see {@link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CamelCase}).
17853  * 
17854  * @class
17855  */
17856 pvc.options.ext.LegendPanelExtensionPoints = function(){};
17857         
17858         
17859         
17860         
17861 /**
17862  * The extension point of the top-most panel mark of the legend panel.
17863  * 
17864  * <p>
17865  * This panel includes the item {@link #panel} child mark.
17866  * </p>
17867  * 
17868  * @type pvc.options.marks.PanelExtensionPoint
17869  */
17870 pvc.options.ext.LegendPanelExtensionPoints.prototype.area = undefined;
17871 /**
17872  * The extension point of the dot mark (the marker's shape) of a legend item.
17873  * 
17874  * <p>See also {@link #markerPanel}.</p>
17875  * 
17876  * @type pvc.options.marks.DotExtensionPoint
17877  */
17878 pvc.options.ext.LegendPanelExtensionPoints.prototype.dot = undefined;
17879 /**
17880  * The extension point of the label mark of a legend item.
17881  * 
17882  * <p>See also {@link #panel}.</p>
17883  * 
17884  * @type pvc.options.marks.LabelExtensionPoint
17885  */
17886 pvc.options.ext.LegendPanelExtensionPoints.prototype.label = undefined;
17887 /**
17888  * The extension point of the legend item 
17889  * <i>marker</i> panel.
17890  * 
17891  * <p>
17892  * The legend item marker panel includes 
17893  * the {@link #dot} and 
17894  * the {@link #rule} child marks.
17895  * </p>
17896  * 
17897  * <p>See also {@link #panel}.</p>
17898  * 
17899  * @type pvc.options.marks.PanelExtensionPoint
17900  */
17901 pvc.options.ext.LegendPanelExtensionPoints.prototype.markerPanel = undefined;
17902 /**
17903  * The extension point of the legend 
17904  * <i>item</i> panel mark.
17905  * 
17906  * <p>
17907  * The legend item panel includes
17908  * the {@link #markerPanel} and 
17909  * the {@link #label} child marks.
17910  * </p>
17911  * 
17912  * @type pvc.options.marks.PanelExtensionPoint
17913  */
17914 pvc.options.ext.LegendPanelExtensionPoints.prototype.panel = undefined;
17915 /**
17916  * The extension point of the rule mark (the marker's line) of a legend item.
17917  * 
17918  * <p>See also {@link #markerPanel}.</p>
17919  * 
17920  * @type pvc.options.marks.RuleExtensionPoint
17921  */
17922 pvc.options.ext.LegendPanelExtensionPoints.prototype.rule = undefined;
17923 /**
17924  * The options documentation class of the chart title panel.
17925  * 
17926  * @class
17927  * @extends pvc.options.panels.TitlePanel
17928  */
17929 pvc.options.panels.ChartTitlePanel = function(){};
17930         
17931         
17932         
17933         
17934 /**
17935  * The docking position of the panel.
17936  * 
17937  * @type pvc.options.varia.PanelPosition
17938  * @default 'top'
17939  * @category Layout
17940  */
17941 pvc.options.panels.ChartTitlePanel.prototype.position = undefined;
17942 /**
17943  * The font of the panel.
17944  * <p>
17945  * See the supported font format in
17946  * {@link http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/fonts.html#font-shorthand}
17947  * 
17948  * @type string
17949  * @default '14px sans-serif'
17950  * @category Style
17951  */
17952 pvc.options.panels.ChartTitlePanel.prototype.font = undefined;

17959 pvc.options.panels.CartesianAxisTitlePanel = function(){};

17971 pvc.options.panels.CartesianAxisTitlePanel.prototype.paddings = null;

17977  * @category Layout
17978  * @constant
17979  */
17980 pvc.options.panels.CartesianAxisTitlePanel.prototype.position = null;
17981 /**

17983  * <p>
17984  * See the supported font format in
17985  * {@link http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/fonts.html#font-shorthand}
17986  * 
17987  * @type string
17988  * @default '12px sans-serif'
17989  * @category Style
17990  */
17991 pvc.options.panels.CartesianAxisTitlePanel.prototype.font = undefined;
17992 /**
17993  * The options documentation class of the title panel.
17994  * 
17995  * @class
17996  * @extends pvc.options.panels.DockedPanel
17997  * @abstract
17998  */
17999 pvc.options.panels.TitlePanel = function(){};
18000         
18001         
18002         
18003         
18004 /**
18005  * Indicates if the title panel is visible.
18006  * <p>
18007  * The default value is 
18008  * <tt>true</tt>, if the 
18009  * <tt>title</tt> property is non-empty,
18010  * and 
18011  * <tt>false</tt>, otherwise.
18012  * 
18013  * @type boolean
18014  * @category Layout
18015  */
18016 pvc.options.panels.TitlePanel.prototype.visible = undefined;
18017 /**
18018  * The extension points of the title panel.
18019  * 
18020  * @type pvc.options.ext.TitlePanelExtensionPoints
18021  * @category Style
18022  */
18023 pvc.options.panels.TitlePanel.prototype.extensionPoints = undefined;
18024 /**
18025  * The extension points of the title panel.
18026  * <p>
18027  * Title extension points can also be specified directly at the chart options level.
18028  * <p>
18029  * To use an extension point you must find its full name.
18030  * If it is the chart's title panel, by joining:
18031  * 
18032  * <ol>
18033  * 
18034  * <li>chart title panel property name: 
18035  * <tt>title</tt></li>
18036  * 
18037  * <li>extension property (ex: 
18038  * <tt>label</tt>)</li>
18039  * 
18040  * <li>the "_" character</li>
18041  * 
18042  * <li>extension sub-property (ex: 
18043  * <tt>textStyle</tt>)</li>
18044  * </ol>
18045  * and obtaining, for the examples, the camel-cased name: 
18046  * <tt>titleLabel_textStyle</tt>
18047  * (see {@link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CamelCase}).
18048  * <p>
18049  * If it is the title panel of an axis, by joining:
18050  * 
18051  * <ol>
18052  * 
18053  * <li>chart axis panel property name (ex: 
18054  * <tt>xAxis</tt>)</li>
18055  * 
18056  * <li>axis panel title property name: 
18057  * <tt>title</tt></li>
18058  * 
18059  * <li>extension property (ex: 
18060  * <tt>label</tt>)</li>
18061  * 
18062  * <li>the "_" character</li>
18063  * 
18064  * <li>extension sub-property (ex: 
18065  * <tt>textStyle</tt>)</li>
18066  * </ol>
18067  * and obtaining, for the examples, the camel-cased name: 
18068  * <tt>xAxisTitleLabel_textStyle</tt>
18069  * (see {@link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CamelCase}).
18070  * 
18071  * @class
18072  */
18073 pvc.options.ext.TitlePanelExtensionPoints = function(){};
18074         
18075         
18076         
18077         
18078 /**
18079  * The extension point of the top-level panel mark.
18080  * <p>
18081  * This extension point, having no own name,
18082  * coincides with the property name of the panel.
18083  * For example, for the chart's title panel:
18084  * 
18085  * <tt>title_fillStyle</tt>.
18086  * 
18087  * @type pvc.options.marks.PanelExtensionPoint
18088  */
18089 pvc.options.ext.TitlePanelExtensionPoints.prototype._ = undefined;
18090 /**
18091  * The extension point of the title label mark.
18092  * 
18093  * @type pvc.options.marks.LabelExtensionPoint
18094  */
18095 pvc.options.ext.TitlePanelExtensionPoints.prototype.label = undefined;
18096 /**
18097  * The namespace of plot options classes.
18098  * 
18099  * @namespace
18100  */
18101 pvc.options.plots = {};
18102 
18103 /**
18104  * The options documentation class for 
18105  * specifying trending options for a plot.
18106  * <p>
18107  * Each trend type may define additional options.
18108  * Specifying additional options requires using object notation
18109  * for the trend option, like in the following example:
18110  * 
18111  * <pre>
18112  *             var chartOptions = {
18113  *                 trend: {
18114  *                     type:    'moving-average',
18115  *                     label:   'My Trend',
18116  *                     periods: 4 // additional option of the 'moving-average' trend type
18117  *                 }
18118  *             };
18119  *             
18120  * </pre>
18121  * Trending is performed after null-interpolation,
18122  * so that it takes the null-interpolated datums into account. 
18123  * 
18124  * @class
18125  */
18126 pvc.options.varia.PlotTrending = function(){};
18127         
18128         
18129         
18130         
18131 /**
18132  * A description to show next to the trended data.
18133  * <p>
18134  * The description shows next to legend items and 
18135  * in auto-generated tooltips.
18136  * <p>
18137  * The default value is the description of the associated trend type.  
18138  * 
18139  * @type string
18140  */
18141 pvc.options.varia.PlotTrending.prototype.label = undefined;
18142 /**
18143  * The type of trend to perform on the data of the associated plot.
18144  * <p>
18145  * The specified trend type must have been 
18146  * previously defined in the CCC library, 
18147  * through the 
18148  * <tt>pvc.trends.define</tt> method.
18149  * <p>
18150  * Some trend types come with the CCC library. 
18151  * Currently these are:
18152  * 
18153  * <dl>
18154  * 
18155  * <dt>'linear'</dt>
18156  * 
18157  * <dd>
18158  * performs a 
18159  * <bb>simple linear regression</bb>
18160  * (see {@link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_linear_regression})
18161  * </dd>
18162  * 
18163  * <dt>'moving-average'</dt>
18164  * 
18165  * <dd>
18166  * performs a simple moving average
18167  * (see {@link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moving_average});
18168  * the additional option 
18169  * <tt>periods</tt>, which defaults to 
18170  * <tt>3</tt>, and must not be less than 
18171  * <tt>2</tt>, 
18172  * may be specified to control the number of data points of the average window.
18173  * </dd>
18174  * 
18175  * <dt>'weighted-moving-average'</dt>
18176  * 
18177  * <dd>
18178  * performs a weighted moving average
18179  * (see {@link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moving_average});
18180  * the additional option 
18181  * <tt>periods</tt>, which defaults to 
18182  * <tt>3</tt>, and must not be less than 
18183  * <tt>2</tt>, 
18184  * may be specified to control the number of data points of the average window.
18185  * </dd>
18186  * </dl> 
18187  * 
18188  * @type string
18189  */
18190 pvc.options.varia.PlotTrending.prototype.type = undefined;
18191 /**
18192  * The options documentation class of the 
18193  * <b>point</b> plot 
18194  * used for the second plot of categorical charts.
18195  * 
18196  * @class
18197  * @extends pvc.options.plots.PointPlot
18198  */
18199 pvc.options.plots.Plot2PointPlot = function(){};
18200         
18201         
18202         
18203         
18204 /**
18205  * The index of the color axis to use for the plot.
18206  * 
18207  * @type number
18208  * @default 2
18209  * @category Axes
18210  */
18211 pvc.options.plots.Plot2PointPlot.prototype.colorAxis = undefined;
18212 /**
18213  * Indicates if the visual elements show dots/markers
18214  * in each point's position.
18215  * 
18216  * @type boolean
18217  * @default true
18218  * @category Style
18219  */
18220 pvc.options.plots.Plot2PointPlot.prototype.dotsVisible = undefined;
18221 /**
18222  * Indicates if the visual elements are connected
18223  * with lines.
18224  * 
18225  * @type boolean
18226  * @default true
18227  * @category Style
18228  */
18229 pvc.options.plots.Plot2PointPlot.prototype.linesVisible = undefined;
18230 /**
18231  * The alignment of a value label 
18232  * relative to its corresponding visual element position.
18233  * 
18234  * @type pvc.options.varia.MarkAnchor
18235  * @default 
18236  * @category Style
18237  */
18238 pvc.options.plots.Plot2PointPlot.prototype.valuesAnchor = undefined;
18239 /**
18240  * The options documentation class of the 
18241  * <b>point</b> plot 
18242  * used for trends of categorical charts.
18243  * 
18244  * @class
18245  * @extends pvc.options.plots.PointPlot
18246  */
18247 pvc.options.plots.TrendPointPlot = function(){};

18253  * The index of the color axis to use for the plot.
18254  * 
18255  * @type number
18256  * @default 2
18257  * @category Axes
18258  */
18259 pvc.options.plots.TrendPointPlot.prototype.colorAxis = undefined;
18260 /**
18261  * The null interpolation mode is not supported by this plot type.
18262  * 
18263  * @type pvc.options.varia.NullInterpolationMode

18267 pvc.options.plots.TrendPointPlot.prototype.nullInterpolationMode = null;

18272  * @category Data

18275 pvc.options.plots.TrendPointPlot.prototype.trend = null;
18276 /**
18277  * Indicates if the visual elements are connected
18278  * with lines.
18279  * 
18280  * @type boolean
18281  * @default true
18282  * @category Style
18283  */
18284 pvc.options.plots.TrendPointPlot.prototype.linesVisible = undefined;
18285 /**

18287  * <b>metric point</b> plot 
18288  * used for trends of scatter charts.
18289  * 
18290  * @class
18291  * @extends pvc.options.plots.MetricPointPlot
18292  */
18293 pvc.options.plots.TrendMetricPointPlot = function(){};
18294         
18295         
18296

18298 /**
18299  * The index of the color axis to use for the plot.
18300  * 
18301  * @type number
18302  * @default 2
18303  * @category Axes
18304  */
18305 pvc.options.plots.TrendMetricPointPlot.prototype.colorAxis = undefined;

18308  *

18313 pvc.options.plots.TrendMetricPointPlot.prototype.orthoAxis = 1;

18329 pvc.options.plots.TrendMetricPointPlot.prototype.trend = null;

18332  * with lines.

18335  * @default true

18337  */
18338 pvc.options.plots.TrendMetricPointPlot.prototype.linesVisible = undefined;
18339 /**
18340  * The trend does not contain null size values.
18341  * 
18342  * @type pvc.options.varia.DotShapeType
18343  * @category Style
18344  * @constant
18345  */
18346 pvc.options.plots.TrendMetricPointPlot.prototype.nullShape = null;
18347 /**
18348  * The namespace of formatting options classes.
18349  * 
18350  * @namespace
18351  */
18352 pvc.options.format = {};
18353 
18354 /**
18355  * The options documentation of the format provider class.
18356  * <p>
18357  * A format provider contains formats for main value types and main modes in which these are formatted.
18358  * Currently, it contains the following formats:
18359  * {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider#number} ,
18360  * {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider#percent},
18361  * {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider#date} and
18362  * {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider#any}.
18363  * 
18364  * <p>
18365  * Format providers exist in, and can be configured at,
18366  * three levels, from most specific to least specific:
18367  * </p>
18368  * 
18369  * <dl>
18370  * 
18371  * <dt>
18372  * <b>Dimension Type</b></dt>
18373  * 
18374  * <dd>
18375  * Most formatting operations use a dimension type's format provider to obtain a format.
18376  * <p>
18377  * By default, the unconfigured properties of a dimension type's format provider
18378  * inherit the corresponding value obtained from the chart's format provider.
18379  * <p>
18380  * A dimension type's format provider is configured through
18381  * the option {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#format}.
18382  * </dd>
18383  * 
18384  * <dt>
18385  * <b>Chart</b></dt>
18386  * 
18387  * <dd>
18388  * The chart's format provides defaults for all formatting operations done in the chart.
18389  * <p>
18390  * The unconfigured properties of a chart's format provider
18391  * inherit the corresponding value obtained from the global format provider
18392  * (any format provider directly or indirectly inherits from the global format provider).
18393  * <p>
18394  * A chart's format provider is configured
18395  * through the option {@link pvc.options.charts.BasicChart#format}.
18396  * </dd>
18397  * 
18398  * <dt>
18399  * <b>Global</b></dt>
18400  * 
18401  * <dd>
18402  * Allows changing the default formats used by all charts.
18403  * <p>
18404  * The global format provider exists in 
18405  * <tt>pvc.data.format.defaults</tt>.
18406  * And can also be accessed by its alias 
18407  * <tt>cdo.format.defaults</tt>.
18408  * 
18409  * <p>
18410  * Using the auxiliary method 
18411  * <tt>def.configure</tt>,
18412  * global defaults can be configured the following way:
18413  * 
18414  * <pre>
18415  * def.configure(pvc.data.format.defaults, {
18416  *     number: {
18417  *         mask: "#,0.00",
18418  *         style: {
18419  *             decimal: ",",
18420  *             group: "."
18421  *         }
18422  *     },
18423  *     date: "%m %Y"
18424  * });
18425  *                         
18426  * </pre>
18427  * 
18428  * <p>
18429  * 
18430  * <p>
18431  * Configuring global defaults can also be done
18432  * by using the format provider and contained objects' accessor methods
18433  * (which follow a similar structure to that of the here documented options):
18434  * 
18435  * <pre>
18436  * pvc.data.format.defaults
18437  *     .number().mask("#,0.00");
18438  * 
18439  * pvc.data.format.defaults
18440  *     .style()
18441  *         .decimal(",")
18442  *         .group(".");
18443  * 
18444  * pvc.data.format.defaults
18445  *     .date("%m %Y");
18446  *                         
18447  * </pre>
18448  * 
18449  * <p>
18450  * </dd>
18451  * </dl>
18452  * 
18453  * <h2>
18454  * Internationalization
18455  * </h2>
18456  * 
18457  * <p>
18458  * Get, set, create and configure different format providers arranged by language.
18459  * <p>
18460  * The default language is 
18461  * <i>en-us</i> but can also be accessed with an empty string.
18462  * It's configuration is the same as the global defaults in cdo.
18463  * </p>
18464  * 
18465  * <p>
18466  * 
18467  * <b>Warning:</b> If you change cdo global defaults, the configuration for the default
18468  * language 
18469  * <i>en-us</i> will also change, so changing them is not recommended.
18470  * </p>
18471  * 
18472  * <dl>
18473  * 
18474  * <dt>Create or configure a format provider by specifying a language and the configuration object</dt>
18475  * 
18476  * <dd>
18477  * 
18478  * <p>
18479  * 
18480  * <pre>
18481  * cdo.format.language('fr-fr', {
18482  *     number: {
18483  *         mask:              '#,0.##',
18484  *         style: {
18485  *             integerPad:    '0',
18486  *             fractionPad:   '0',
18487  *             decimal:       ',',
18488  *             group:         ' ',
18489  *             groupSizes:    [3],
18490  *             abbreviations: ['k','m', 'b', 't'],
18491  *             negativeSign:  '-',
18492  *             currency:      '€'
18493  *         }
18494  *     },
18495  *     date: {
18496  *         mask:              '%d/%m/%Y'
18497  *     }
18498  * });
18499  *                         
18500  * </pre>
18501  * 
18502  * <p>
18503  * </dd>
18504  * 
18505  * <dt>Create or configure multiple format providers</dt>
18506  * 
18507  * <dd>
18508  * 
18509  * <p>
18510  * 
18511  * <pre>
18512  * cdo.format.language({
18513  *     'en-us': {
18514  *         number: {
18515  *             mask:              '0,0 Currency',
18516  *         },
18517  *         date: '%Y/%m/%d'
18518  *     },
18519  *     'en-gb': {
18520  *         number: {
18521  *             mask:              '0.00 Abbreviation',
18522  *             style: {
18523  *                 abbreviations: ['k','m', 'b', 't']
18524  *             }
18525  *     }
18526  * });
18527  *                         
18528  * </pre>
18529  * 
18530  * <p>
18531  * </dd>
18532  * 
18533  * <dt>Get the format provider of a specific language</dt>
18534  * 
18535  * <dd>
18536  * 
18537  * <p>
18538  * 
18539  * <pre>
18540  * cdo.format.language('pt-pt');
18541  *                         
18542  * </pre>
18543  * 
18544  * <p>
18545  * </dd>
18546  * </dl>
18547  * 
18548  * @class
18549  */
18550 pvc.options.format.FormatProvider = function(){};
18551         
18552         
18553         
18554         
18555 /**
18556  * The format function/object used to format values of other data types,
18557  * like 
18558  * <i>string</i>, 
18559  * <i>boolean</i> and 
18560  * <i>object</i>.
18561  * <p>
18562  * When a function is specified,
18563  * it is the {@link pvc.options.format.CustomFormat#formatter} property
18564  * of a new custom format that replaces the current format.
18565  * <p>
18566  * When an object is specified, it configures the 
18567  * <i>current</i> format object.
18568  * <p>
18569  * Alternatively, a direct instance of {@link pvc.options.format.CustomFormat}
18570  * can be specified, replacing the existing format.
18571  * <p>
18572  * The global default custom formatter formats 
18573  * <i>nully</i>
18574  * values as an empty string and
18575  * other values by calling their 
18576  * <i>#toString()</i> method.
18577  * 
18578  * @type function|object|pvc.options.format.CustomFormat
18579  */
18580 pvc.options.format.FormatProvider.prototype.any = undefined;
18581 /**
18582  * The format function/object used to format date/time objects.
18583  * <p>
18584  * When a string is specified,
18585  * it is the {@link pvc.options.format.DateFormat#mask} property of
18586  * a new date format that replaces the current format.
18587  * <p>
18588  * When a function is specified,
18589  * it is the {@link pvc.options.format.CustomFormat#formatter} property
18590  * of a new custom format that replaces the current format.
18591  * <p>
18592  * When an object is specified, it configures the 
18593  * <i>current</i> format object.
18594  * <p>
18595  * Alternatively, direct instances of
18596  * {@link pvc.options.format.DateFormat} and {@link pvc.options.format.CustomFormat}
18597  * can be specified, replacing the existing format.
18598  * <p>
18599  * The global default date mask id 
18600  * <tt>"%Y/%m/%d"</tt>.
18601  * 
18602  * @type string|function|object|pvc.options.format.DateFormat|pvc.options.format.CustomFormat
18603  */
18604 pvc.options.format.FormatProvider.prototype.date = undefined;
18605 /**
18606  * The format function/object used to format numbers in a general way.
18607  * <p>
18608  * When a string is specified,
18609  * it is the {@link pvc.options.format.NumberFormat#mask} property of
18610  * a new number format that replaces the current format.
18611  * <p>
18612  * When a function is specified,
18613  * it is the {@link pvc.options.format.CustomFormat#formatter} property
18614  * of a new custom format that replaces the current format.
18615  * <p>
18616  * When an object is specified, it configures the 
18617  * <i>current</i> format object.
18618  * <p>
18619  * Alternatively, direct instances of
18620  * {@link pvc.options.format.NumberFormat} and {@link pvc.options.format.CustomFormat}
18621  * can be specified, replacing the existing format.
18622  * <p>
18623  * The global default of the number format mask is 
18624  * <tt>"#,0.##"</tt> —
18625  * numbers are first rounded to decimal places.
18626  * Then, they are formatted with a thousands group separator and only significant decimal places.
18627  * <p>
18628  * See the {@link pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle}
18629  * for information on the global default number styles.
18630  * <p>
18631  * See also related information in {@link pvc.options.charts.BasicChart#valueFormat}.
18632  * 
18633  * @type string|function|object|pvc.options.format.NumberFormat|pvc.options.format.CustomFormat
18634  */
18635 pvc.options.format.FormatProvider.prototype.number = undefined;
18636 /**
18637  * The format function/object used to format percentage numbers.
18638  * <p>
18639  * The formatting function should multiply the numeric value by 100.
18640  * <p>
18641  * This function is used whenever a chart needs to show percentages,
18642  * like in the tooltips of a stacked chart or the percentages shown in a Pie chart.
18643  * <p>
18644  * When a string is specified,
18645  * it is the {@link pvc.options.format.NumberFormat#mask} property of
18646  * a new number format that replaces the current format.
18647  * <p>
18648  * When a function is specified,
18649  * it is the {@link pvc.options.format.CustomFormat#formatter} property
18650  * of a new custom format that replaces the current format.
18651  * <p>
18652  * When an object is specified, it configures the 
18653  * <i>current</i> format object.
18654  * <p>
18655  * Alternatively, direct instances of
18656  * {@link pvc.options.format.NumberFormat} and {@link pvc.options.format.CustomFormat}
18657  * can be specified, replacing the existing format.
18658  * <p>
18659  * The global default percent mask is 
18660  * <tt>"#,0.#%"</tt> —
18661  * numbers are first multiplied by 100 and then
18662  * rounded to one decimal place.
18663  * Then, they are formatted
18664  * with a thousands group separator,
18665  * with only significant decimal places,
18666  * and by appending a "%" character.
18667  * <p>
18668  * See the {@link pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle}
18669  * for information on the global default number styles.
18670  * <p>
18671  * See also related information in {@link pvc.options.charts.Chart#percentValueFormat}.
18672  * 
18673  * @type string|function|object|pvc.options.format.NumberFormat|pvc.options.format.CustomFormat
18674  */
18675 pvc.options.format.FormatProvider.prototype.percent = undefined;
18676 /**
18677  * The options documentation of the number format.
18678  * <p>
18679  * A 
18680  * <i>number format</i> formats numbers by using a formatting mask.
18681  * The mask syntax is mostly compatible with VB's 
18682  * <i>format()</i> function mask syntax.
18683  * See {@link http://apostate.com/programming/vb-format-syntax.html}
18684  * for more information on the mask syntax (only the number related subset is relevant).
18685  * <p>
18686  * See {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider} for
18687  * more information on inheritance of formatting configurations.
18688  * 
18689  * @class
18690  */
18691 pvc.options.format.NumberFormat = function(){};
18692         
18693         
18694         
18695         
18696 /**
18697  * The formatting mask.
18698  * 
18699  * @type string
18700  * @default ''
18701  */
18702 pvc.options.format.NumberFormat.prototype.mask = undefined;
18703 /**
18704  * The number format style to use.
18705  * 
18706  * @type string|pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle
18707  */
18708 pvc.options.format.NumberFormat.prototype.style = undefined;
18709 /**
18710  * The options documentation of the number format style class.
18711  * <p>
18712  * The options in this class are mostly useful for
18713  * customizing locale sensitive styles of number formatting.
18714  * <p>
18715  * See {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider} for
18716  * more information on inheritance of formatting configurations.
18717  * 
18718  * @class
18719  */
18720 pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle = function(){};
18721         
18722         
18723         
18724         
18725 /**
18726  * The array of abbreviations.
18727  * There is no maximum number of units abbreviations.
18728  * The first element of the array represents the Thousands unit,
18729  * the second Millions, the third Billions...
18730  * 
18731  * @type list(string)
18732  * @default ['k','m','b','t']
18733  */
18734 pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle.prototype.abbreviations = undefined;
18735 /**
18736  * Gets or sets the currency symbol to use in place of the "¤" mask character.
18737  * <p>
18738  * The 
18739  * <b>currency sign</b> ¤ is a character used to denote an unspecified currency.
18740  * Its unicode is U+00A4 and
18741  * its HTML entities are &#164; and &curren;
18742  * <p>
18743  * See {@link http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Currency_sign_(typography)} for
18744  * more information on the currency sign character.
18745  * 
18746  * @type string
18747  * @default '$'
18748  */
18749 pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle.prototype.currency = undefined;
18750 /**
18751  * The character to use in place of the "." mask character.
18752  * The decimal point separates the integer and fraction parts of the number.
18753  * 
18754  * @type string
18755  * @default '.'
18756  */
18757 pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle.prototype.decimal = undefined;
18758 /**
18759  * The character to use in place of a "0" mask character in the fractional part.
18760  * 
18761  * @type string
18762  * @default '0'
18763  */
18764 pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle.prototype.fractionPad = undefined;
18765 /**
18766  * The character to use in place of the "," mask character.
18767  * The group separator groups integer digits according to the sizes in 
18768  * <tt>groupSizes</tt>.
18769  * Grouping can be disabled, independently of the mask, by specifying "".
18770  * 
18771  * @type string
18772  * @default ','
18773  */
18774 pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle.prototype.group = undefined;
18775 /**
18776  * The array of group sizes.
18777  * The last group is repeated indefinitely.
18778  * The array must contain at least one element.
18779  * 
18780  * @type list(number)
18781  * @default [3]
18782  */
18783 pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle.prototype.groupSizes = undefined;
18784 /**
18785  * The character to use in place of a "0" mask character in the integer part.
18786  * 
18787  * @type string
18788  * @default '0'
18789  */
18790 pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle.prototype.integerPad = undefined;
18791 /**
18792  * The negative sign character.
18793  * The negative sign is used to indicate a negative number
18794  * when a mask does not have a negative values section.
18795  * The negative sign is placed leftmost in the resulting string.
18796  * The negative sign is also used for showing a negative exponent,
18797  * in scientific notation.
18798  * 
18799  * @type string
18800  * @default '-'
18801  */
18802 pvc.options.format.NumberFormatStyle.prototype.negativeSign = undefined;
18803 /**
18804  * The options documentation of the date format class.
18805  * <p>
18806  * A 
18807  * <i>date format</i> formats numbers by using a formatting mask.
18808  * <p>
18809  * The format mask is the same as that expected by the 
18810  * <tt>strftime</tt> function in C.
18811  * See the protovis' documentation of the function 
18812  * <tt>pv.Format.date</tt>
18813  * for the actual format mask syntax
18814  * ({@link http://mbostock.github.io/protovis/jsdoc/symbols/pv.Format.date.html}).
18815  * <p>
18816  * The current date format implementation does not provide a configurable date style.
18817  * <p>
18818  * The 
18819  * <tt>null</tt> value is formatted as an empty string.
18820  * <p>
18821  * See {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider} for
18822  * more information on inheritance of formatting configurations.
18823  * 
18824  * @class
18825  */
18826 pvc.options.format.DateFormat = function(){};
18827         
18828         
18829         
18830         
18831 /**
18832  * The formatting mask.
18833  * 
18834  * @type string
18835  */
18836 pvc.options.format.DateFormat.prototype.mask = undefined;
18837 /**
18838  * The options documentation of the custom format class.
18839  * <p>
18840  * A 
18841  * <i>custom format</i> formats arbitrary values with a
18842  * custom, user supplied, formatting function:
18843  * {@link pvc.options.format.CustomFormat#formatter}.
18844  * <p>
18845  * See {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider} for
18846  * more information on inheritance of formatting configurations.
18847  * 
18848  * @class
18849  */
18850 pvc.options.format.CustomFormat = function(){};
18851         
18852         
18853         
18854         
18855 /**
18856  * The custom formatting function.
18857  * <p>
18858  * The signature of this function is that of a dimension formatter.
18859  * 
18860  * @returns {string}
18861  * The string that is the formatted value.
18862  * Only the 
18863  * <tt>null</tt> value 
18864  * <i>should</i> have the empty string
18865  * as the formatted value.
18866  * 
18867  * @method
18868  * @this null
18869  * @param {any} value
18870  * The value to format.
18871  * 
18872  * @param {any} [sourceValue]
18873  * The source (or raw) value,
18874  * when the value was read from a data source,
18875  * or 
18876  * <tt>undefined</tt>, otherwise.
18877  * <p>
18878  * In the case where the raw value is 
18879  * a Google-table-like cell, 
18880  * it is the value of its 
18881  * <i>v</i>
18882  * property that is passed to this argument.
18883  * 
18884  */
18885 pvc.options.format.CustomFormat.prototype.formatter = function(){};
18886 /**
18887  * The options documentation class of a data dimensions reader.
18888  * <p>
18889  * A dimensions reader is executed for each row of a
18890  * data source to convert values of one or more columns
18891  * into one or more atoms of certain dimensions.
18892  * <p>
18893  * Together, a set of dimensions readers,
18894  * are executed to fully convert
18895  * each data source row into atoms of the defined dimension types.
18896  * The atoms of each row are used to construct a datum.
18897  * <p>
18898  * The mentioned data source row is called the 
18899  * <i>logical row</i>.
18900  * Depending on the data source format (crosstab or relational),
18901  * the actual rows carry different informaton.
18902  * The 
18903  * <i>logical row</i> is a normalized view of each row of the data source,
18904  * independent of its format.
18905  * <p>
18906  * A dimensions reader can be configured in the following ways:
18907  * 
18908  * <dl>
18909  * 
18910  * <dt>specify 
18911  * <tt>names</tt> but not 
18912  * <tt>reader</tt></dt>
18913  * 
18914  * <dd>
18915  * names are paired with any specified indexes, from left to right;
18916  * excess indexes feed dimensions whose name starts with the last specified name (a dimension group);
18917  * excess names are fed with the 
18918  * <i>non reserved</i>indexes
18919  * that follow the last specified index (or 0, if none);
18920  * indexes explicitly specified in dimensions readers are all
18921  * reserved beforehand
18922  * </dd>
18923  * 
18924  * <dt>specify 
18925  * <tt>indexes</tt> but not 
18926  * <tt>names</tt> and 
18927  * <tt>reader</tt></dt>
18928  * 
18929  * <dd>
18930  * the specified indexes become reserved but are not read,
18931  * and so are effectively ignored
18932  * </dd>
18933  * 
18934  * <dt>specify both 
18935  * <tt>reader</tt> and 
18936  * <tt>names</tt></dt>
18937  * 
18938  * <dd>
18939  * any specified indexes are reserved,
18940  * and no pairing is performed between these and the specified names;
18941  * the reader function may
18942  * read any column from the 
18943  * <i>logical row</i> and
18944  * return atoms from any of the dimensions specified in 
18945  * <tt>names</tt>;
18946  * atoms of stated dimensions, that are not returned,
18947  * result in a 
18948  * <i>null</i> value;
18949  * this form allows, for example,
18950  * splitting a value in the 
18951  * <i>logical row</i> into two dimensions.
18952  * </dd>
18953  * </dl>
18954  * 
18955  * @class
18956  */
18957 pvc.options.DimensionsReader = function(){};
18958         
18959         
18960         
18961         
18962 /**
18963  * The index or indexes of the columns that the reader reads
18964  * from each 
18965  * <i>logical row</i>.
18966  * <p>
18967  * Only one dimensions reader can state that it reads a given index
18968  * (although a dimensions reader function may sneek into any columns it likes).
18969  * 
18970  * @type number|string|list(number|string)
18971  * @category General
18972  */
18973 pvc.options.DimensionsReader.prototype.indexes = undefined;
18974 /**
18975  * The name or names of the dimensions that the reader reads
18976  * from each 
18977  * <i>logical row</i>.
18978  * <p>
18979  * When the argument is a string, it can be a list of names,
18980  * separated by the character ",".
18981  * <p>
18982  * Only one dimensions reader or dimensions calculation can
18983  * read or calculate a given dimension.
18984  * 
18985  * @type string|list(string)
18986  * @category General
18987  */
18988 pvc.options.DimensionsReader.prototype.names = undefined;
18989 /**
18990  * A dimensions reader function,
18991  * reads the values of dimensions,
18992  * for each 
18993  * <i>logical row</i>.
18994  * <p>
18995  * When unspecified,
18996  * one is created that performs a simple
18997  * mapping between the specified names and indexes.
18998  * <p>
18999  * A dimensions reader function can be specified
19000  * to perform non-simple operations over the read columns,
19001  * like the following:
19002  * 
19003  * <ul>
19004  * 
19005  * <li>
19006  * combine values from two or more columns into a single dimension,
19007  * </li>
19008  * 
19009  * <li>
19010  * split the value of one column into more than one dimension,
19011  * </li>
19012  * 
19013  * <li>
19014  * feed a dimension with correlated data read from an external data source.
19015  * </li>
19016  * </ul>
19017  * <p>
19018  * Dimensions reader functions need not be specifed to perform
19019  * conversion or formatting operations of a single column.
19020  * For those cases, the dimension type's
19021  * {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#converter}
19022  * and
19023  * {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#formatter}
19024  * are more appropriate.
19025  * <p>
19026  * Also, when the value of a dimension
19027  * is calculated from the value of other dimensions,
19028  * a dimensions calculation may be more appropriate:
19029  * see {@link pvc.options.DimensionsCalculation}.
19030  * <p>
19031  * The function may read columns whose indexes were not
19032  * "reserved" in 
19033  * <tt>indexes</tt>.
19034  * Those columns might be read by other readers,
19035  * possibly default ones created by the translator.
19036  * 
19037  * @returns {undefined}
19038  * @method
19039  * @this pvc.data.Data
19040  * @param {list(any)} logicalRow
19041  * The 
19042  * <i>logical row</i> array.
19043  * 
19044  * @param {object} outAtoms
19045  * An object that should be filled with read raw values,
19046  * each placed in a property with the name
19047  * of the corresponding dimension.
19048  * <p>
19049  * It is also possible that the values be the atoms themselves,
19050  * a technique that can be used to achieve greater performance,
19051  * when a dimension only has two or three possible values.
19052  * 
19053  * @category General
19054  */
19055 pvc.options.DimensionsReader.prototype.reader = function(){};
19056 /**
19057  * A dimensions calculation allows the values of a dimension
19058  * to be calculated from the typed values of
19059  * the other non-calculated dimensions.
19060  * <p>
19061  * While a dimensions reader could achieve the same result,
19062  * it works by reading values from the 
19063  * <i>logical table</i>,
19064  * accessing it by index.
19065  * That would require the knowledge of the indexes
19066  * in which the desired dimensions were,
19067  * which is many times not true,
19068  * specially when the mapping between
19069  * dimensions and 
19070  * <i>logical table</i> indexes is determined automatically
19071  * by the data translator.
19072  * 
19073  * @class
19074  */
19075 pvc.options.DimensionsCalculation = function(){};
19076         
19077         
19078         
19079         
19080 /**
19081  * A dimensions calculation function.
19082  * 
19083  * @returns {undefined}
19084  * @method
19085  * @this null
19086  * @param {pvc.data.Complex} datum
19087  * The complex (Datum or Data) instance 
19088  * whose dimensions are being calculated.
19089  * 
19090  * @param {object} outAtoms
19091  * An object that should be filled with read raw or typed values, 
19092  * each placed in a property with the name
19093  * of the corresponding dimension.
19094  * <p>
19095  * It is also possible that the values be the atoms themselves, 
19096  * a technique that can be used to achieve greater performance,
19097  * when a dimension only has two or three possible values. 
19098  * 
19099  * @category General
19100  */
19101 pvc.options.DimensionsCalculation.prototype.calculation = function(){};
19102 /**
19103  * The name or names of the dimensions that
19104  * are calculated by the calculation.
19105  * <p>
19106  * When the argument is a string, it can be a list of names,
19107  * separated by the character ",".
19108  * <p>
19109  * Only one dimensions calculation or dimensions reader
19110  * can calculate or read a given dimension.
19111  * 
19112  * @type string|list(string)
19113  * @category General
19114  */
19115 pvc.options.DimensionsCalculation.prototype.names = undefined;
19116 /**
19117  * The options documentation class of a dimension type.
19118  * 
19119  * @class
19120  */
19121 pvc.options.DimensionType = function(){};
19122         
19123         
19124         
19125         
19126 /**
19127  * A function that compares two different and non-null values of the dimension's
19128  * {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#valueType}.
19129  * <p>
19130  * When unspecified,
19131  * a default natural order comparer function
19132  * is applied to the continuous value types:
19133  * {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Number} and
19134  * {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Date}.
19135  * <p>
19136  * Dimension types that do not have a comparer
19137  * function "compare" their values by "input order"
19138  * - order of first appearance, in the data source.
19139  * 
19140  * @returns {number}
19141  * The number 0 if the two values have the same order, 
19142  * a negative number if 
19143  * <tt>a</tt> is before 
19144  * <tt>b</tt>, and
19145  * a positive number if 
19146  * <tt>a</tt> is after 
19147  * <tt>b</tt>.
19148  * 
19149  * @method
19150  * @this null
19151  * @param {any} a
19152  * The first value to compare.
19153  * 
19154  * @param {any} b
19155  * The second value to compare.
19156  * 
19157  * @category Data
19158  */
19159 pvc.options.DimensionType.prototype.comparer = function(){};
19160 /**
19161  * Converts a non-null raw value,
19162  * as read from the data source,
19163  * into a value of the dimension's {@link #valueType}.
19164  * <p>
19165  * The returned value
19166  * need not have the type of the dimension's value type.
19167  * Yet,
19168  * it must be such that
19169  * the associated value type's cast function can
19170  * convert it to the dimension's value type.
19171  * In this way,
19172  * only "non-standard" conversions
19173  * need to be handled with a converter function.
19174  * <p>
19175  * Values that are not convertible by the dimension's value type
19176  * cast function become null.
19177  * <p>
19178  * Also, note that the only value type that
19179  * does not have a cast function is the
19180  * {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Any}.
19181  * <p>
19182  * When unspecified and
19183  * the value type is {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Date},
19184  * and the option {@link #rawFormat} is specified
19185  * a default converter is created for it.
19186  * 
19187  * @returns {any}
19188  * The converted value.
19189  * 
19190  * @method
19191  * @this null
19192  * @param {any} sourceValue
19193  * The non-null source value to convert.
19194  * <p>
19195  * In the case where the raw value to convert is 
19196  * a Google-table-like cell, 
19197  * it is the value of its 
19198  * <tt>v</tt>
19199  * property that is passed to this argument.
19200  * 
19201  * @category Data
19202  */
19203 pvc.options.DimensionType.prototype.converter = function(){};
19204 /**
19205  * Indicates if a dimension type should be considered discrete
19206  * or continuous.
19207  * <p>
19208  * Only dimension types whose {@link #valueType}
19209  * is one of
19210  * {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Number} or
19211  * {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Date}
19212  * can be continuous.
19213  * <p>
19214  * Some chart types support binding
19215  * a continuous or a discrete dimension to a visual role,
19216  * yielding different visual results.
19217  * An example is the "color" visual role of the Metric Line/Dot charts.
19218  * Another example is the Line/Dot/Area chart that supports
19219  * both a continuous or a discrete dimension in its "category" visual role.
19220  * <p>
19221  * The default value dependends on the value of {@link #valueType}.
19222  * If it can be continuous, then the default value is 
19223  * <tt>false</tt>.
19224  * If it cannot, the default value is 
19225  * <tt>true</tt>.
19226  * 
19227  * @type boolean
19228  * @category Data
19229  */
19230 pvc.options.DimensionType.prototype.isDiscrete = undefined;
19231 /**
19232  * A function that converts a non-null value of the dimension's
19233  * {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#valueType}
19234  * into a string that (uniquely) identifies
19235  * the value in the dimension.
19236  * <p>
19237  * The default key function is
19238  * the standard JavaScript 
19239  * <tt>String</tt> function,
19240  * and is suitable for most value types.
19241  * <p>
19242  * If the dimension's value type is one of
19243  * {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Any} or
19244  * {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Object}
19245  * the 
19246  * <tt>String</tt> function may not be suitable to
19247  * identify the values.
19248  * <p>
19249  * If more than one value has a given key,
19250  * only the first one will be stored in the dimension.
19251  * 
19252  * @returns {string}
19253  * The corresponding key.
19254  * 
19255  * @method
19256  * @this null
19257  * @param {any} value
19258  * The non-null value to convert.
19259  * 
19260  * @category Data
19261  */
19262 pvc.options.DimensionType.prototype.key = function(){};
19263 /**
19264  * A protovis format string that is to parse the raw value.
19265  * <p>
19266  * Currently, this option is ignored unless the
19267  * option {@link #converter} is unspecified
19268  * and the value type is
19269  * {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Date}.
19270  * <p>
19271  * When the chart option
19272  * {@link pvc.options.charts.Chart#timeSeriesFormat},
19273  * is specified,
19274  * and the value type is
19275  * {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Date},
19276  * it is taken as the 
19277  * <i>default value</i> of this option.
19278  * <p>
19279  * A converter function is created to parse
19280  * raw values with the specified format string.
19281  * 
19282  * @type string
19283  * @category Data
19284  */
19285 pvc.options.DimensionType.prototype.rawFormat = undefined;
19286 /**
19287  * The type of value that dimensions of this type will hold.
19288  * 
19289  * @type pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType
19290  * @default null
19291  * @category Data
19292  */
19293 pvc.options.DimensionType.prototype.valueType = undefined;
19294 /**
19295  * The dimension type's format provider.
19296  * <p>
19297  * When the option {@link #formatter} is specified, this one is ignored.
19298  * <p>
19299  * When a string, it is the mask of the
19300  * {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider#number} or
19301  * {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider#date} formats,
19302  * depending on the dimension's the dimension's
19303  * {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#valueType},
19304  * of a new format provider that replaces the current one.
19305  * <p>
19306  * When a function, it is the formatter of the
19307  * {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider#number} or
19308  * {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider#date} custom formats,
19309  * depending on the dimension's the dimension's
19310  * {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#valueType},
19311  * of a new format provider that replaces the current one.
19312  * Note that specifying a function to this property is equivalent to specifying
19313  * {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#formatter}.
19314  * <p>
19315  * When an object is specified,
19316  * it configures the 
19317  * <i>current</i> format object.
19318  * <p>
19319  * Alternatively,
19320  * a direct instance of
19321  * {@link pvc.options.format.FormatProvider},
19322  * can be specified, replacing the existing format provider.
19323  * Instead, specifying
19324  * {@link pvc.options.format.NumberFormat},
19325  * {@link pvc.options.format.DateFormat},
19326  * or {@link pvc.options.format.CustomFormat}
19327  * configures the existing format provider.
19328  * <p>
19329  * A protovis format string that is to format a value of
19330  * the dimension's
19331  * {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#valueType}.
19332  * <p>
19333  * When unspecified,
19334  * and the dimension type's value type is {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Date},
19335  * and the property {@link #rawFormat} is specified,
19336  * a format string is derived from the later by replacing the "-" character with a "/" character.
19337  * <p>
19338  * Otherwise, the dimension type's format provider inherits its
19339  * property values from the chart's format provider.
19340  * 
19341  * @type string|function|object|pvc.options.format.FormatProvider
19342  * @category Presentation
19343  */
19344 pvc.options.DimensionType.prototype.format = undefined;
19345 /**
19346  * A function that formats a value,
19347  * possibly null,
19348  * of the dimension's
19349  * {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#valueType}.
19350  * <p>
19351  * Note that, the chart option
19352  * {@link pvc.options.charts.BasicChart#valueFormat},
19353  * is used to build a default formatter function
19354  * for numeric dimensions of the "value" dimension group.
19355  * <p>
19356  * When unspecified and
19357  * the value type is {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Number},
19358  * a default formatter is created that formats numbers with two decimal places.
19359  * <p>
19360  * When unspecified and
19361  * the value type is {@link pvc.options.varia.DimensionValueType#Date},
19362  * and the option {@link #format} is specified (or implied)
19363  * a default formatter is created for it.
19364  * <p>
19365  * Otherwise a value is formatted by calling
19366  * the standard JavaScript 
19367  * <tt>String</tt> function on it.
19368  * 
19369  * @returns {string}
19370  * The string that is the formatted value.
19371  * Only the 
19372  * <tt>null</tt> value 
19373  * <i>should</i> have the empty string
19374  * as the formatted value.
19375  * 
19376  * @method
19377  * @this null
19378  * @param {any} value
19379  * The value to format.
19380  * 
19381  * @param {any} [sourceValue]
19382  * The source (or raw) value,
19383  * when the value was read from a data source,
19384  * or 
19385  * <tt>undefined</tt>, otherwise.
19386  * <p>
19387  * In the case where the raw value is 
19388  * a Google-table-like cell, 
19389  * it is the value of its 
19390  * <i>v</i>
19391  * property that is passed to this argument.
19392  * 
19393  * @category Presentation
19394  */
19395 pvc.options.DimensionType.prototype.formatter = function(){};
19396 /**
19397  * Indicates if values of this dimension type
19398  * should be hidden from the user.
19399  * <p>
19400  * This option is useful to hide auxiliar dimensions that are used to:
19401  * 
19402  * <ul>
19403  * 
19404  * <li>hold extra data, required for drill-down purposes</li>
19405  * 
19406  * <li>
19407  * complete the minimal working information a chart needs to work,
19408  * like, for example,
19409  * a "series" dimension created automatically by a chart if
19410  * its required "series" visual role was not unbound
19411  * </li>
19412  * </ul>
19413  * <p>
19414  * The only place where the values of a dimension that is not bound to a visual role
19415  * are shown to the user is the tooltip, as it is formatted by default.
19416  * To prevent this,
19417  * set the dimension type's 
19418  * <tt>isHidden</tt> option to 
19419  * <tt>true</tt>.
19420  * 
19421  * @type boolean
19422  * @default false
19423  * @category Presentation
19424  */
19425 pvc.options.DimensionType.prototype.isHidden = undefined;
19426 /**
19427  * The name of the dimension type as it is shown to the user.
19428  * <p>
19429  * The label 
19430  * <i>should</i> be unique.
19431  * <p>
19432  * The default value is built from the dimension name,
19433  * by converting the first character to upper case.
19434  * 
19435  * 
19436  * @type string
19437  * @category Presentation
19438  */
19439 pvc.options.DimensionType.prototype.label = undefined;
19440 /**
19441  * The options documentation class of a sliding window for real time use.
19442  * <p>
19443  * A sliding window defines the range of data to be kept, this is,
19444  * all data outside the window is removed and therefore lost.
19445  * <p>
19446  * The intended use is the real time case where data is being delivered at some rate and
19447  * the window is "sliding", allowing the visualization of the most recent set of data in
19448  * a given domain span.
19449  * <p>
19450  * When slidingWindow is set to 
19451  * <tt>true</tt>, the following properties have the
19452  * indicated default values:
19453  * 
19454  * <ul>
19455  * 
19456  * <li>
19457  * 
19458  * <tt>preserveMap</tt>: 
19459  * <tt>true</tt>,
19460  * see {@link pvc.options.axes.DiscreteColorAxis#preserveMap};
19461  * </li>
19462  * 
19463  * <li>
19464  * 
19465  * <tt>preserveRatio</tt>: 
19466  * <tt>true</tt>,
19467  * see {@link pvc.options.axes.AnyContinuousCartesianAxis#preserveRatio};
19468  * </li>
19469  * 
19470  * <li>
19471  * 
19472  * <tt>fixedLength</tt> -
19473  * if the sliding window length ({@link #length}) is defined,
19474  * fixed length is set to this value;
19475  * see
19476  * {@link pvc.options.axes.AnyContinuousCartesianAxis#fixedLength} and
19477  * {@link pvc.options.axes.SizeAxis#fixedLength};
19478  * </li>
19479  * 
19480  * <li>
19481  * 
19482  * <tt>comparer</tt>: 
19483  * <tt>def.ascending</tt>,
19484  * see {@link pvc.options.DimensionType#comparer}.
19485  * </li>
19486  * </ul>
19487  * 
19488  * @class
19489  */
19490 pvc.options.SlidingWindow = function(){};
19491         
19492         
19493         
19494         
19495 /**
19496  * The name of the dimension associated with the sliding window.
19497  * 
19498  * <h2>Default</h2>
19499  * When unspecified, the sliding window will be associated with the dimension of the base axis.
19500  * 
19501  * @type string
19502  * @category Chart > Data
19503  */
19504 pvc.options.SlidingWindow.prototype.dimension = undefined;
19505 /**
19506  * The domain length to show on the sliding window axis.
19507  * <p>
19508  * When unspecified, the sliding window is considered disabled.
19509  * 
19510  * @type number|string|pvc.options.varia.TimeInterval
19511  * @category Chart > Data
19512  */
19513 pvc.options.SlidingWindow.prototype.length = undefined;
19514 /**
19515  * A function that, given a dataset, selects the data to be removed.
19516  * 
19517  * <h2>Default</h2>
19518  * The default function uses the length specified in {@link #length},
19519  * to remove every datum which is not in the domain window.
19520  * <p>
19521  * If the dimension specified in {@link #dimension} is not numerical or 
19522  * <tt>Date</tt>,
19523  * no datum is removed.
19524  * 
19525  * @returns {pvc.data.Datum[]}
19526  * An array with the datums to remove.
19527  * 
19528  * @method
19529  * @param {pvc.data.Datum[]} allData
19530  * An array of datums to evaluate.
19531  * 
19532  * @category Chart > Data
19533  */
19534 pvc.options.SlidingWindow.prototype.select = function(){};
19535 /**
19536  * The namespace of various options-related helper types.
19537  * 
19538  * @namespace
19539  */
19540 pvc.options.varia = {};
19541 
19542 /**
19543  * Controls if and how the selection can be cleared by the user.
19544  * 
19545  * @class
19546  * @enum
19547  * @extends string
19548  */
19549 pvc.options.varia.ChartClearSelectionMode = function(){};
19550         
19551         
19552         
19553 /**
19554  * The user can click on any 
19555  * <i>empty area</i>
19556  * 
19557  * <i>inside</i> the chart to clear the selection.
19558  * 
19559  * @value 'emptySpaceClick'
19560  */
19561 pvc.options.varia.ChartClearSelectionMode.prototype.EmptySpaceClick = 'emptySpaceClick';
19562 /**
19563  * The user has no way to explicitly fully clear the selection.
19564  * <p>
19565  * It is still possible to clear the selection,
19566  * if the selection behavior performs a toggling operation.
19567  * <p>
19568  * Selection can always be cleared by code.
19569  * 
19570  * @value 'manual'
19571  */
19572 pvc.options.varia.ChartClearSelectionMode.prototype.Manual = 'manual';
19573 /**
19574  * The main direction of drawing.
19575  * 
19576  * @class
19577  * @enum
19578  * @extends string
19579  */
19580 pvc.options.varia.ChartOrientation = function(){};
19581         
19582         
19583         
19584 /**
19585  * Horizontal direction.
19586  * 
19587  * @value 'horizontal'
19588  */
19589 pvc.options.varia.ChartOrientation.prototype.Horizontal = 'horizontal';
19590 /**
19591  * Vertical direction.
19592  * 
19593  * @value 'vertical'
19594  */
19595 pvc.options.varia.ChartOrientation.prototype.Vertical = 'vertical';
19596 /**
19597  * The sides of a child panel, the source, 
19598  * that can be aligned with 
19599  * a target side of a parent panel.
19600  * <p>
19601  * The alignment side must be 
19602  * orthogonal to the side of 
19603  * the {@link pvc.options.varia.PanelPosition}.
19604  * <p>
19605  * By combining the alignment source
19606  * with the {@link pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentTarget},
19607  * different alignment combinations can be achieved.
19608  * <p>
19609  * The alignment target side must be 
19610  * parallel to the side of source alignment.
19611  * 
19612  * @class
19613  * @enum
19614  * @extends string
19615  */
19616 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentSource = function(){};
19617         
19618         
19619         
19620 /**
19621  * The bottom side of the child panel 
19622  * is placed at the same position as the
19623  * target side of the parent panel. 
19624  * 
19625  * @value 'bottom'
19626  */
19627 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentSource.prototype.Bottom = 'bottom';
19628 /**
19629  * The horizontal center position of the child panel 
19630  * is placed at the same position as the
19631  * target side of the parent panel. 
19632  * 
19633  * @value 'center'
19634  */
19635 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentSource.prototype.Center = 'center';
19636 /**
19637  * The left side of the child panel 
19638  * is placed at the same position as the
19639  * target side of the parent panel.
19640  * 
19641  * @value 'left'
19642  */
19643 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentSource.prototype.Left = 'left';
19644 /**
19645  * The vertical center position of the child panel 
19646  * is placed at the same position as the
19647  * target side of the parent panel. 
19648  * 
19649  * @value 'middle'
19650  */
19651 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentSource.prototype.Middle = 'middle';
19652 /**
19653  * The right side of the child panel 
19654  * is placed at the same position as the
19655  * target side of the parent panel.
19656  * 
19657  * @value 'right'
19658  */
19659 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentSource.prototype.Right = 'right';
19660 /**
19661  * The top side of the child panel 
19662  * is placed at the same position as the
19663  * target side of the parent panel.
19664  * 
19665  * @value 'top'
19666  */
19667 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentSource.prototype.Top = 'top';
19668 /**
19669  * The sides of a parent panel, the target, 
19670  * with which the alignment side of a source child panel 
19671  * can be aligned to.
19672  * <p>
19673  * The alignment target side must be 
19674  * parallel to the side of source alignment.
19675  * <p>
19676  * Wherever an alignment target argument is found,
19677  * a value of type 
19678  * <tt>number</tt>,
19679  * a numeric 
19680  * <tt>string</tt> or 
19681  * a numeric percentage 
19682  * <tt>string</tt>, 
19683  * may also be specified.
19684  * <p>
19685  * In this case, 
19686  * these specify the position of alignment, 
19687  * from the left or top sides,
19688  * whichever is parallel to the alignment source side.
19689  * <p>
19690  * For example, if the source alignment side is 
19691  * <tt>'right'</tt>
19692  * and the target alignment specifies 
19693  * <tt>'10%'</tt>,
19694  * then the right side of the child panel would be
19695  * placed at a position of 
19696  * 10% of the parent panel's client width
19697  * from the parent's left side.
19698  * 
19699  * @class
19700  * @enum
19701  * @extends string
19702  */
19703 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentTarget = function(){};
19704         
19705         
19706         
19707 /**
19708  * The source side of the child panel
19709  * is placed at the same position as the
19710  * bottom side of the parent panel.
19711  * 
19712  * @value 'bottom'
19713  */
19714 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentTarget.prototype.Bottom = 'bottom';
19715 /**
19716  * The source side of the child panel
19717  * is placed at the same position as the
19718  * horizontal center position of the parent panel.
19719  * 
19720  * @value 'center'
19721  */
19722 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentTarget.prototype.Center = 'center';
19723 /**
19724  * The source side of the child panel
19725  * is placed at the same position as the
19726  * left side of the parent panel.
19727  * 
19728  * @value 'left'
19729  */
19730 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentTarget.prototype.Left = 'left';
19731 /**
19732  * The source side of the child panel
19733  * is placed at the same position as the
19734  * vertical center position of the parent panel.
19735  * 
19736  * @value 'middle'
19737  */
19738 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentTarget.prototype.Middle = 'middle';
19739 /**
19740  * The source side of the child panel
19741  * is placed at the same position as the
19742  * vertical center position of the 
19743  * 
19744  * <i>page</i> height of the parent panel.
19745  * <p>
19746  * The page height differs from the chart height
19747  * in that the 
19748  * page height is by definition 
19749  * the value initially specified in 
19750  * {@link pvc.options.charts.BasicChart#height},
19751  * and the chart height 
19752  * can grow if layout so requires it,
19753  * like it does in 
19754  * <i>small multiples</i> charts.
19755  * <p>
19756  * The page middle alignment allows, 
19757  * for example, 
19758  * placing the legend panel in 
19759  * the middle of the screen height,
19760  * even though the height of the chart
19761  * may have become much larger.
19762  * 
19763  * @value 'page-middle'
19764  */
19765 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentTarget.prototype.PageMiddle = 'page-middle';
19766 /**
19767  * The source side of the child panel
19768  * is placed at the same position as the
19769  * right side of the parent panel.
19770  * 
19771  * @value 'right'
19772  */
19773 pvc.options.varia.PanelAlignmentTarget.prototype.Right = 'right';
19774 /**
19775  * The source side of the child panel
19776  * is placed at the same position as the
